author: jawford
title: Mum who stole £2,700 of groceries in self-service checkout scam was ‘desperate’ because her ‘husband walked out and left her with a mountain of debt’
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments THE mum caught stealing £2,700 worth of groceries using fake barcodes carried out the scam out of sheer “desperation”, her family claimed. 
Kylie Milner, from Brisbane, Australia, struggled to support her daughter when her husband allegedly walked out, leaving her with a mortgage and a “mountain of debt”. Facebook 3 Kylie Milner was caught stealing £2,700 worth of groceries using fake barcodes 
She was handed a nine-month suspended jail sentence after pleading guilty to sticking fake barcodes on groceries before scanning them through self-service checkouts. 
Her financial difficulties were explained in a letters written to a court this week, which heard she spent three months stealing items from Queensland supermarket stores . 
In a reference to the court, her sister Michelle wrote: “All her problems started when her husband walked out on her and left her with a mortgage (and) a mountain of debt and left her to raise their daughter on their own. 
“She is really trying to turn her life around.” 
According to Daily Mail Australia , her sister-in-law, Lisa, wrote that “she made some very bad decisions at a time of desperation”. 
She described Milner as a “beautiful, loving, caring good individual who just made some wrong choices in life”. Getty Images 3 The mum has been caught scamming self-serve checkouts by sticking barcodes on products 
Milner used self-service checkouts multiple times a day at major supermarket chains Coles and Woolworths, The Queensland Times reported. 
She is understood to have copied barcodes from 65c fried noodles and put them on products. 
Items stolen included coffee machines, toilet paper, cleaning products, sheet sets, meats, frozen seafood, and toiletries. 
She swiped more than 30 slabs of meat from the store over 12 visits in August, court papers said. 
Police were tipped off after a staff manager noticed a “regular female customer” always looked “nervous” while going to pay. Alamy 3 Police found glue sticks and copies of the fraudulent barcodes on her computer 
When cops went to her home, they found glue sticks and copies of the fraudulent barcodes on her computer along with items with the fake labels stuck on them. 
Milner, who appeared in Ipswich Magistrates Court on Monday, pleaded guilty to 31 counts of fraud, three counts of attempted fraud and and one count of possessing a drug related utensil. Her defence lawyer Matthew Fairclough said she was “struggling financially”and was motivated by “need rather than greed”. 
But magistrate Virginia Sturges said: “The restitution is very conservative and I estimate it is very likely you stole a considerable amount more.” 
Milner was given a suspended nine-month prison sentenced and ordered to pay £951 compensation to Coles and £1274 to Woolworths.
